title-group.article-title: To strive is human, to abuse malign: Ddiscrimination and non-accidental violence of professional athletes without employee-style statutory protection

fn.label: Contributors
fn.p: VLR developed the idea and wrote the paper. VES cowrote the article.

fn.label: Author note
fn.p: The authors emphasise that they make no claims about the conduct of British Cycling or UK Sport. This article is merely intended to highlight a lack of employment-style protection for athletes.

fn.label: Correction notice
fn.p: This article has been corrected since it published Online First. The first author's name has been corrected.

meta-value.named-content: Corrections at this stage should be limited to those that are essential. Extensive corrections will delay the time to publication and may also have to be approved by the Editor. Changes can not be made after the article has published online. Please acknowledge that you have read this message.

I acknowledge this statement. All changes made relate to (1) the consistent use of the term non-accidental violence throughout the Discussion piece, (2) improvement in sentence structure and grammar, and (3) the inclusion of the term governing bodies in paragraph 6 and 9. Thank you for conducting the final copy-editing the piece. Regards, Victoria Roberts.
The words 'nonOA' are showing in the top left corner of page two. Please remove.
We have fixed, the standart statement of copyrights statement, please check.

body.p: Corresponding author: Victoria Roberts
Postal address: Level 10, The Spot, 198 Berkeley Street, Department of Management and Marketing, Faculty of Business and Economics, The University of Melbourne, Carlton, VIC, 3010, Australia.
Department: Department of Management and Marketing, Faculty of Business and Economics, Institution: The University of Melbourne, Melbourne, VICTORIA, Australia
Email address: victoria.roberts@unimelb.edu.au,
Co-author: Victor Sojo.
Department: Department of Management and Marketing, Faculty of Business and Economics, Institution: The University of Melbourne, Melbourne, VICTORIA, Australia

A recent judgmentjudgement from a landmark employment case against British Cycling and UK Sport found that Jess Varnish, a former professional British cyclist, was neither an employee nor a worker of either organisation within the meaning of the Employment Rights Act 1996 or the Equality Act 2010. The relationship between the cyclist and British Cycling was judged to be more akin to a relationship between a student and a University (eg, service provider), and that funding provided to the cyclist by UK Sport was analogous to a grant.1

Jess Varnish brought her claims of unfair dismissal (ie, termination of her Athlete Performance Award, which is a means-tested financial contribution towards an athlete’s living expenses), direct sex discrimination, victimisation, and unlawful detriment for having made protected disclosures (ie, whistle-blowing) to the Employment Tribunal.1 She sought protections offered to employees or workers but not offered to professional athletes.

The case highlights a problem: athletes are not considered to be employees nor workers and therefore are not entitled to employee nor worker protection, but no other equivalent form of protection for athletes exists.

Why does this matter? Numerous studies investigating athletes’ experiences show that discrimination and non-accidental violence including psychological, physical, and sexual abuse, and neglect of athletes are protracted and pervasive issues in sport, particularly at the elite level.2 The concequences of Ddiscrimination and non-accidental violence are related to serious and long-term. nNegative outcomes for athletes, includinge: injury, impaired performance, marginalisation,, and mental and physical health difficulties.2

Extensive research shows that discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence are structurally and culturally embedded in the sporting world.3 An imbalance in power relationships— – a key predictor of discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence— – is a structural feature of sport. An imbalance in power manifests in three ways. First, high status authority figures such as coaches with the power to (de)select athletes can use intimidating, coercive and manipulative tactics to exert control with few consequences for them and less resistance from the athletes.4 Second, the inequity in bargaining power between parties prevents athletes from negotiating the terms that govern their relationship with their national sports organisation.1 Third, the ‘“culture of silence’” in sport prevents athletes from speaking- up about grievances for fear of experiencing backlash (eg, being excluded, scapegoated, harassed or punished).5 These factors combine to systemiatically disempower athletes. This is a paradox given it is the athlete, not the coach or manager who pulls the oar, defends the goal, or performs the tumble.

Causal factors go beyond power imbalances. The overarching winner-take-all reward structure, whichthat allocates a disproportionate amount of rewards to the winner, creates a perverse incentive to ‘“win at anyll costs’” and may induce athletes, coaches and managers to use whatever means necessary, including discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence, to achieve results.5 It may also motivate national sports organisations and governing bodies to turn a blind eye to discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence when the absolute number of medals is small, and the number of medals won determines future funding.

The cultural context of sport is also responsible for the systemic vulnerability of athletes. Research highlights three factors that combine to explicitly and implicitly enable, and, in some instances, actively encourage, discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence: (1) an uncritical acceptance and unquestioned commitment to the dominant values of sport6; (2) the belief that discriminatory and abusive practices are ‘“functional’” for motivating and making athletes or teams perform better7; and (3) norms that create a sense of permissiveness to discriminate and abuse.6

Athletes deserve better. They should be protected to the same degree as any other employee or worker. The fact that society is willing to bask in the glory of Olympic Mmedal winners but tolerates the discrimination and abuse of athletes and fails to provide adequate redress once it occurs is unconscionable. It calls into question the social contract between government bodies, national sports organisations and the public, in which the welfare of the individual athlete is sacrificed on the altar of national glory.

Given the circumstances, what might we do to protect athletes? An immediate solution is required to ensure athletes have statutory protection against discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence while training under an Athlete Agreement. To improve transparency and accountability for services provided to athletes, complaint handling processes and investigations conducted by national sports organisations and governing bodies need to be reportable to an independent oversight body with investigatory powers.8

In addition, a long-term whole-of-system approach is required to correct the systemic injustice and address the structural and cultural factors leading to discrimination and abusenon-accidental violence of athletes. This approach calls for a change in attitude towards sport— – an attitude whichthat preserves the integrity of individual athletes while collectively striving for success— - by all of society, including governments, the public, sports organisations (including administrators, regulators, and training personnel), sponsors, and current and future athletes and their families.
The authors would like to thank Bill Harley, David Merrett and Edwin Harari for their very helpful comments on earlier drafts of this paper.
The authors have not identified any competing interests in the writing of this Discussion paper.
This paper was not funded by any external body to the university where the paper was written.

Required statement: The authors wish to emphasise that they make no claims about the conduct of British Cycling or UK Sport. This article is merely intended to highlight a lack of employment-style protection for athletes.

email-content.mail-subject: Proof of your article for British Journal of Sports Medicine - 10.1136/bjsports-2019-100693

mail-body.p: I’m pleased to provide the proof of your article, which is available on our author proofing system here:

Please submit any corrections then ensure you click ‘Approve’ to complete the author proofing process. Signing off the paper will send the article back to the Production team so they can make any changes.
Please note, the online author proofing system cannot be used in the browser Internet Explorer. Please review your proofs in Google Chrome.

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.bjsm@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

This is the only opportunity you will have to correct your article before publication, so please review it carefully. Please ensure you respond to queries listed in the article. Minor errors cannot be corrected after publication and any serious scientific errors will result in a formal correction.
Reprints: If you wish to purchase reprints of your article, please fill in the reprint form.
British Journal of Sports Medicine Production Team

A PDF version of the proof is available to download and review, but all corrections must be submitted using the online system. Please contact us at production.bjsm@bmj.com if you need any help using this.

If you need to replace any figures or supplementary files, DO NOT attempt to upload them to the system but please send them to the Production Editor at production.bjsm@bmj.com . We will provide a further PDF proof for you to check if they have been replaced.
